Message.Msg: It is nice to be a 20% owner of the behemoth. Let's get it IPO's ttp://www.cnbc.com/id/100298520?__source=yahoo%7Cheadline%7Cquote%7Ctext%7C&par=yahoo

Message.Title: Move Over Amazon - Here Comes Alibaba Group
Message.Msg: Tmall, run by China's second-largest Internet company Alibaba Group, has already overtaken popular consumer to consumer (C2C) portal or online auctioneer, eBay in sales this year, according to Euromonitor. Tmall's sales are projected to hit $32.5 billion in 2012, compared to $27.7 billion for eBay. Just five years old - spun off from sister website Taobao, a Chinese version of eBay - Tmall's success is based purely on sales in one single market. Unlike its American counterparts, which run global operations with over 50 percent of Amazon's sales coming from outside of the U.S., according to Euromonitor, Tmall operates only in Greater China. "What you have to take into account is that they [Tmall] still haven't expanded abroad. it's just operating in the Chinese market and seeing the sales volume it's seeing at the moment," Lamine Lahouasnia, senior retail analyst at Euromonitor in London said. "If it were to start thinking about pushing the brand abroad perhaps to another Chinese speaking region of the world, we could potentially see the overtaking of Amazon happen a lot sooner," he added.

Message.Title: Yahoo Takes on Instagram with Flickr Upgrade
Message.Msg: Yahoo just totally revamped its Flickr app for iOS with Instagram-like filters. Yahoo hadn't updated the app since last year, so new Flickr fits in quite nicely with Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer's commitment to a mobile-first strategy. The new app features a simpler sign-up process, 16 camera filters and full groups capabilities, which used to only be available on Flickr.com. Unlike Instagram, Flickr provides support for Twitter, in addition to Facebook, Tumblr, and email. Earlier this week, Instagram pulled the plug on Twitter, making it no longer possible to view Instagram photos in your Twitter stream.

Message.Title: Yahoo Takes on Instagram with Flickr Upgrade
Message.Msg: Unlike Instagram, Flickr provides support for Twitter, in addition to Facebook, Tumblr, and email. Earlier this week, Instagram pulled the plug on Twitter, making it no longer possible to view Instagram photos in your Twitter stream.

Message.Title: Marissa Mayer Just Embarrassed Twitter And Instagram With The New Flickr Mobile App Update
Message.Msg: Today, Yahoo! (YHOO) released the latest update of its once dominant photo sharing application Flickr for mobile on iOS. Long story short, it’s the best mobile photo app out there at the moment. The co1done is very fond of Marissa Mayer...

Topic.Title: Marissa Mayer Just Embarrassed Twitter And Instagram With The New Flickr Mobile App Update

Message.Msg: A few short weeks ago, if you backed out the value of Yahoo’s cash and its investments in Alibaba Group and Yahoo Japan, Yahoo’s core business was worth NEGATIVE $3 billion. If this new Flickr update is any indicator, all of Yahoo’s properties are about to be Mayer-ized. And that means they’re collectively worth a lot more than they’re being valued at today. Flickr now is the best mobile photo app on the market, in my view. It’s still not the biggest. Instagram has over 100 million users. But Flickr was at 80 million mobile users before this update. Flickr has a serious shot at taking back the top spot that was once theirs. Oh, and they will always play nice with everyone: iOS, Android, Facebook, and Twitter.

Topic.Title: Coldone Annoys Me

Message.Msg: Calling everybody that doesn't blindly fall in love with Coldone "a new hotmodel alias" is like calling every black guy that makes you laugh Dave Chappelle. However, I do suppose it's easy to make that assumption considering this was my first post. Truthfully, I've been following this board since right around the time Marissa took over. I decided to finally make my first post today out of sheer boredom. I can assure you though that this is my one and only ID. I'm not Hotmodel or anybody else on this board. In fact, I disagree with Hotmodel on many things, but I think it's because we're playing different games. I like to make money when stocks go up. It seems Hotmodel likes to make money when stocks go down. Nothing wrong with that. We may be playing different games but we'll both have our opportunity to win. What annoys me about Coldone is his general attitude about investing. It seems he wants me to believe that he's perfect or something. More in-the-know and smarter than anyone who has ever invested before. Drop the act and get real. But! For reference: Coldone asked everybody if we would buy or sell YHOO @ 19 with $1m. I would buy. With maximum leverage. Like I said, I'm bullish on YHOO. I believe it is severely undervalued. I believe we're going to see a stronger performance out of YHOO than we saw out of AOL over the last 12 months. And in case you don't know, that's an EXTREMELY strong performance. However, I'm not so delusion that I don't think I could be wrong. It's my experiences that the people that think they're invincible are truly the people that are the most vulnerable.

Message.Title: WHATIS THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN AN AAPL MANAGER AND A YAHOO MANAGER?
Message.Msg: When an AAPL manager messes up (as with iPhone maps, for example), he ends up working somewhere else. When a Yahoo manager messes up (many examples), he ends up being responsible for keeping the spam and political posts off these message boards. That is one reason why AAPL is a well managed company and Yahoo is not.

Message.Title: Got some bad news for everyone - technical breakdown.
Message.Msg: Yahoo fell well below yesterdays low, didn't meet yesterdays high, and closed down on accelerated volume. Tomorrow thousands of people who don't own Yahoo will sell millions of shares on the open market triggering even more selling. By the way the whole market is going to correct. Something radical always happens to Yahoo's stock right before options expiration. Did you really think the stock was going to go up forever. Could see 70 cent drop tomorrow.

Topic.Title: Coldone Annoys Me

Message.Msg: Well, my apologies, then. Like I said, I'm not afraid of being wrong. 90% of the people you meet on these boards are decidedly long or decided short. And it's impossible to convince them that they're not always right. Very few actually play both sides. In fact, I'm biased towards being decidedly long myself. For the most part, I only invest in stocks that I feel if I went into a coma today - I would wake up as a rich man. For this reason, I don't often short my stocks. In fact, the time I spend with a cash position is generally a refreshing little breather from the mayhem. Netflix was probably a good pickup. Solid growth and I believe there's a pretty good chance they'll be snatched up by one of the major tech companies soon. What's their price tag right now? $5bil market cap and some change? I mean, even the Alibaba stake that Yahoo still has is bigger than Netflix. And then you have Apple (who I think is highly likely to end up with Netflix) with $100bil cash on hand. -shrug- Hey, here's a good question for ya: Do you follow Groupon? What do you think their shares will be going for in a year? It's hard to tell, imo. Seems like they're always right on the verge of something really really great or really really horrible.

Message.Title: Standpoint Research Upgrades Microsoft to “Buy” (MSFT)
Message.Msg: Analysts at Standpoint Research upgraded tech giant Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) on Wednesday after a 3 month period of decline as shares now look attractive again. The analysts upgraded MSFT from “Hold” to “Buy” with a price target of $32. The new target is a +17% upside from Tuesday’s closing price of $27.32. Standpoint Research analyst Ronnie Moas notes, “We have gone in-and-out of MSFT twice in the last four years…Since we last exited MSFT in September 2011 the shares have underperformed the Nasdaq and the S&P-500 by 1500 basis points. The stock has dropped 15% in the last three months and once again looks attractive (especially relative to the S&P). “MSFT seems to be on track to compete with its current strategy, well-received new products [Xbox, Windows 8, Surface and Office]and upgrades.” Microsoft shares were up slightly (+0.77%) in premarket trading on Wednesday. The stock is up +5.24% year-to-date. Microsoft is one of the world’s largest software researchers and manufacturers. The company is well known for its Windows operating system products, as well as the Xbox gaming system, Microsoft Office software, and its recent entry into the tablet and smartphone markets. In the most recent quarter, MSFT reported net income of $4.47 billion on revenues of $16 billion.

Topic.Title: SPECIAL DIVIDEND TIME

Message.Msg: The stock was almost $19 two years ago, under Bartz. So, raise your standards. They should do buybacks AND issue a small special dividend. Also, taking the cash and buying things in the internet world has not always turned to be good investments. The shareholders over the past 5 years have had a lot of pain, but you didn't see the board make any sacrifices themselves as they heaped loads of options on themselves, and they still are doing that.
